importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the satellite launch and announcement marks a significant milestone in Pakistan’s space development program, signaling national progress in technological self-reliance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The two-month calibration period after launch places the full operational capability of the H1 satellite within a timeframe that will allow its data to be integrated into national planning and disaster management systems by early 2026.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major advancement in its space program.
The H1 satellite was launched from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, by Pakistan’s space agency SUPARCO.
Hyperspectral technology allows detection of subtle chemical and material changes on Earth’s surface, enhancing applications in agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster management.
The satellite is expected to improve precision agriculture, climate resilience, and management of natural resources such as water and land.
Pakistan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs highlighted the role of the satellite in supporting the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), particularly in geohazard risk identification.
This mission reflects and strengthens Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration.
Pakistan has launched three satellites this year: H1 (hyperspectral), EO-1, and KS-1, with the latter two already fully operational.
It may take approximately two months to calibrate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational.
SUPARCO Chairman Muhammad Yousuf Khan emphasized that the data from H1 will revolutionize agricultural productivity and resource management.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country that launched its first hyperspectral satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is central to the article as the nation launching and utilizing the satellite to advance domestic development and space capabilities.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s space agency responsible for the launch and management of the H1 satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is directly involved in the planning, execution, and operational oversight of Pakistan’s space missions, including the H1 launch.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s first hyperspectral satellite, launched into orbit on October 19, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is the central technological achievement of the article, enabling advanced Earth observation for agriculture, disaster response, and environmental monitoring.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A satellite launch facility located in northwestern China.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch site is significant as it reflects international collaboration between Pakistan and China in space technology.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation that provided launch infrastructure and is a strategic partner to Pakistan in space technology.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China’s role as host of the launch site underscores the strategic space partnership between Pakistan and China, vital to the success and context of the mission.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development initiative linking China’s Xinjiang province to Pakistan’s Gwadar Port.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite’s geohazard monitoring capabilities are expected to support CPEC by improving risk assessment and planning in vulnerable areas.

namedEntities.name: Precision agriculture
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A farming method using data to optimize crop yield and resource use.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hyperspectral data from H1 will enable more efficient and productive farming practices in Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: Environmental monitoring
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The process of tracking environmental changes using satellite data.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite enables real-time monitoring of environmental conditions such as water quality and land degradation.

namedEntities.name: Disaster management
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The planning and response to natural disasters using technological tools.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hyperspectral imaging helps identify damage from natural disasters like floods or landslides, supporting faster response efforts.

namedEntities.name: Water resources
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key natural resource being monitored using the satellite data.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite aids in tracking water availability and quality, essential for sustainable development in Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: Geohazard risks
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Natural risks such as landslides or earthquakes that can impact infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite’s ability to identify geohazards supports safer development along key infrastructure corridors like CPEC.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, marking a major step forward in its space capabilities. The satellite, operated by SUPARCO, is designed to detect subtle material changes on Earth's surface, enabling precise monitoring of agriculture, water resources, environmental conditions, and geohazard risks. This technology is expected to enhance national productivity, support climate resilience, and improve disaster response. The launch also underscores Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China, particularly in the context of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), where accurate geohazard assessments are critical. While full operational capacity is expected after about two months of calibration, the mission signals a broader push to strengthen Pakistan’s space program, which has already sent three satellites into orbit this year.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
